sourceDesc.p: Bibliography and direct anaylsis of the manuscripts

person.name: Albertus Scriptoris de Doesborch
person.note: From the diocese of Utrecht, he obtained the degree of Bachelor at the Paris Faculty of Arts in 1432 and the degree of Master in 1436. He studied theology and received the Bachelor of Theology in 1444. He served several times as procurator and receptor of the German Nation between 1440 and 1446, and as Rector of the University in 1444, 1447–1448, and 1450. In 1444, he was appointed ambassador of the University to King Charles VII, and in 1450, ambassador to the Council of the Gallican Church in Rouen. In 1451, he was active at the University of Orléans. In 1464, he returned to Paris

Mentioned in ms. Praha, NK, X H 21 as the head of the school in which Stanislaus de Welwara copied the texts; head of the school in which Clemens de Melnyk copied the texts transmitted in ms. Stuttgart, Württembergische Landesbibliothek, HB X 2.

person.name: Albertus de Szurkowo
Albert/Wojciech z Szurkowa
person.note: From the Diocese of Poznań. He obtained the title of Baccalaureus at the Faculty of Arts in Prague in 1457 under the master Wenceslaus de Krzizanow. In 1461, he received the license and degree of Magister Artium in Paris. The same year he left Paris for Cracow, where, from 1462, he taught at the Faculty of Arts.

person.name: Ambrosius Allantsee
person.note: He studied at Basel University. He entered the Clunian monastery of St. Alban and later the chartustians in Christgarten, Nördlingen and Kleinbasel. Prior of St. Mang in Füssen. He brought the manuscripts he had copied at Basel University in Füssen (II.lat.1. folio.8, II.lat.1.folio.93, II.lat.1.folio.94, II.lat.1.folio.103, II.lat.1.folio.128, II.lat.1. quarto.33). He died in 1505.

listBibl.bibl: Scarpatetti, Datierte I, 252
Hilg, Lateinische mittelalterliche Handschriften, 13-14

person.name: Andrea de Gambyn
Andrzej z Gąbina
person.note: Matriculated at Krakow in 1465; received a Bachelor’s degree in 1468; obtained a Master’s degree in 1474.

listBibl.bibl: Catalogus 2, 314
Metryka, 315

Andrzej z Gąbina, syn Alberta/Wojciecha (Id: 2015096), in: Corpus Academicum Cracoviense (CAC), URL: http://cac.historia.uj.edu.pl/osoba/2015096_Andrzej_z_G%C4%85bina_syn_Alberta_Wojciecha (accessed: 04.09.2025).

person.name: Andreas de Paradiso
Andrzej z Paradyża
person.note: He received the degree of Bachelor at the University of Kraków in 1468 and obtained the Master’s degree there in 1470.

listBibl.bibl: Andrzej z Paradyża, cysters (Id: 2016015), in: Corpus Academicum Cracoviense (CAC), URL: http://cac.historia.uj.edu.pl/osoba/2016015_Andrzej_z_Parady%C5%BCa_cysters (Dostęp: 31.08.2025).

person.name: Clemens de Melnik
Klemens von Mîlník
person.note: He studied at the Faculty of Arts in Paris, at the school of Albertus Scriptoris in 1449, where he copied the commentaries on logic attributed to Versoris. He identifies himself as originally from Mělník, Bohemia. I could not find any record of him in volumes II and VI of the Auctarium, which concern the Anglo-German Nation, nor in the other volumes of the Auctarium. Astrik Gabriel, the editor of volume VI of the Auctarium, also mentions Clemens de Melnik only in connection with the copy of Versoris's commentary and provides no further information about his career. František Šmahel writes: Es sei aber gleich bemerkt, daß dies die einzige Erwähnung über Klemens von Melnik ist und wir also nicht einmal wissen, ob er von Paris wiederum nach Prag zurückkehrte. For this reason, it cannot be ruled out that he may have died shortly after completing the copy.

listBibl.bibl: Šmahel, "Paris und Prag", 447
Gabriel, "The House of the Poor German Students", 185

person.name: Clemens Parmentarii
Clémens Parmentier
person.note: Clémens Parmentier, a member of the Norman nation, taught at the Faculty of Arts in Paris from the 1440s onward and was appointed rector of the University in October 1451. He studied theology under the direction of Petrus Richeri and obtained his license in 1460. In April 1466, he competed for the position of lector Ethicorum alongside Guillelmus de Curis and Guillelmus Vimon, the latter of whom ultimately received the appointment.
Master to which the commentaries are ascribed

listBibl.bibl: Kałuza, "Cours communs", 174
Sullivan, Parisian Licentiates, II 32, 410

person.name: Christianus Lupi
person.note: Studied at the Collège de Tournai of Paris University as a member of the Anglo-German Nation and obtained the degree of bachelor in 1465. His studies are attested also in ms. Berlin, Staatsbibliotheek Preußischer Kulturbesitz, Ms. theol. qu. 26. He later entered the franciscain convent in Brandeburg.

person.name: Crux de Telcz
Kříž z Telče
person.note: Crux’s studies at King Wenceslas College at Prague University between April and November 1459 are well documented by the large number of colophons he left. He did not obtain any degree, which is not surprising, given that he was Catholic and the situation at Prague University in the 1450s did not favor Catholics. He subsequently worked for the Catholic Church administration, first at St. Vitus Cathedral in Prague (1463–1466), and later in Plzeň (1468–1472). He was ordained in 1463 and joined the Augustinian canonry in Třeboň (Wittingau in German).

person.name: Folpardus de Ameronghen
Folpardus de Hameronghen
Folpardus Hameronge
Fohardus Hameronge
person.note: Native from the diocese of Utrecht. As a member of the German nation at the University of Paris, he obtained the degree of bachelor of Arts in 1448 and the degree of master of Arts in 1449. He later obtained a degree in civil law. He was and procurator of the German Nation in 1451. By 1459, we find him as of the bishop David de Bourgogne
Weijers (and Lohr?) ascribe to him the commentaries on the logical corpus
Master supervising the copy of the commentaries

listBibl.bibl: Weijers, Le travail intellectuel à la faculté des arts de Paris. Textes et maîtres (ca. 1200–1500), II, Turnhout. 1996, p. 90–91.

person.name: Galcerandus Benedicti
Garcerandus Benedicti
person.note: From the diocese of Lerida (diocesis Ilerdensis or Hilardensis), belonged to the French Nation. He studied under Clémens Parmentier, obtained his bachelor degree in 1447 and licensed in 1448 under the master Petrus Caroz. His activity at the Arts Faculty is attested until 1450.

listBibl.bibl: Rouse & Rouse, Illiterati et uxorati, 31
Sullivan, Parisian Licentiates, II, 410.

person.name: Galtherus de Walma
Galtherus de Wervia
Galtherus de Warnia
Galtherus de Varnia
Galtherus de Vernia
Galtherus de Werfia
Galtherus de Veruia

note.p: The colophon of manuscript Paris, BnF, latin 6691 informs us that Galtherus de Walma was a regent master at the Collège de Bourgogne in 1463. According to Paul Bakker, it is probable that this master should be identified with Galtherus de Wervia (also spelled Warnia, Varnia, Vernia, Werfia, Veruia), the author of a commentary on the Isagoge and another on De anima. Bakker argues this identification is plausible due to the various attested spellings of the name and because Galtherus de Wervia was also active at the Collège de Bourgogne during the same period, as evidenced by the colophons of the Isagoge and De anima commentaries.

If this identification is correct, Bakker further argues, then Galtherus de Wervia would also be the author of the commentary on the Ethics transmitted in the Parisian manuscript. While I agree that the identification of Galtherus de Walma with Galtherus de Wervia is plausible, I find Bakker's conclusions regarding the Ethics commentary problematic. First of all, Bakker does not distinguish between the two commentaries transmitted in the Parisian manuscript (the first one covering ff. 2ra–151vb; the second one, ff. 152ra–215v), treating them as if they constituted a single work covering ff. 1r–215v. In reality, these two commentaries – both addressing Books I–IV of the Nicomachean Ethics – have distinct incipits and explicits, as well as different sets of questions. Only the first commentary is anonymous, while the second is explicitly ascribed to Versoris by the scribe. Galtherus de Walma is mentioned only in the colophon of the second commentary, not the first. In this colophon, he is identified as the master under whose supervision the text was copied (sub magistro), which merely indicates that Galtherus de Walma used this commentary in his teaching. It does not, in any way, prove that he authored it.

Galtherus de Wervia – who, if Bakker's hypothesis holds, is to be identified with Galtherus de Walma – originated from the diocese of Utrecht. He began his university studies in 1442 at the University of Cologne. By 1445, he had moved to the University of Paris, where he is recorded as a baccalareus artium affiliated with the German nation. That same year, he incepted under the master Albertus Scriptoris, also from the diocese of Utrecht. In 1457, he enrolled in theological studies. His name appears for the last time in Parisian records in 1472. During this period, he likely licensed in theology, as he is listed in the records of the University of Heidelberg in 1475 as having received his license in theology from Paris. After his time in Heidelberg, he moved to Tübingen, where he earned the title of Doctor of Theology in 1480.

person.note: Master supervising the copy

listBibl.bibl: Weijers, Le travail intellectuel, vol. 3, p. 63–64
Lohr I, 163

P.J.J.M. Bakker, F.J. Kok, Secundum intentionem Doctoris Subtilis: The Commentaries on Porphyry's Isagoge and Aristotle's De anima by Walter of Wervia (ca. 1425–1497), Bulletin de Philosophie Médiévale 56 (2014), 263-279

person.name: Georg Nigri
Georg Schwarz
person.note: Originally from Kaaden (Bohemia), he entered the Dominican Order in Brux in 1452. He studied at the Dominican convent in Leipzig (1456–1458) and Bologna (1459–1461). He lectured as cursor sententiarum in Eichstätt (1461) and was active as a preacher there and in Buchenhüll (1464–1465). He pursued his theological studies at the University of Cologne (1465–1466) and served as lector and preacher at the Dominican convents in Ulm and Eichstätt (1467–1474). He taught theology at the Dominican convent in Regensburg (1478) and continued his theological studies at the University of Ingolstadt (1478–1479). In 1482, he became the general vicar of the Dominican Order in Bohemia. In this capacity, he participated in the General Chapter of the Order in Rome in 1484.

person.name: Georgius de Brabantia
person.note: Born in 1448 in Bourbourg, he was tonsured in 1456 under Bishop Henri de Lorraine-Vaudémont. He became a monk at the Abbey of Saint-Bertin and, from 1493 onwards, served there as archivist and prior. He studied at the Faculty of Arts in Paris in 1471, as attested by his colophon in manuscript Saint-Omer, 597. Likely during the same period, he copied another manuscript now preserved in the same library (Saint-Omer, MS 600), which also belonged to the Abbey of Saint-Bertin. This manuscript contains anonymous commentaries on the logical corpus —distinct from those attributed to Versoris— and features the same kind of rich decoration found in MS 597.

listBibl.bibl: Gil, Saint-Omer gothique, 379
T. Sullivan, Benedictine Monks at the University of Paris: A.D. 1229–1500: A Biographical Register, Leiden, 1995, 77, no. 114
Livesey, Science in the Monastery, 210–212 (MS 597); 216–218 (MS 600)

person.name: Georgius Erber de Aibling
person.note: After studying at the universities of Erfurt (1452) and Vienna (1455), Georgius Erber moved to Paris, where he was affiliated with the Anglo-German Nation and was a member of the Collège de la Marche (1460–1463). He obtained the degree of Bachelor of Arts in 1461 and the degree of Master in 1463. During this period, he acquired two volumes containing commentaries attributed to Versoris – one on natural philosophy and the other on logic – which he brought with him when, shortly after completing his studies, he moved to Coburg

listBibl.bibl: Auctarium II, col. 948, l. 19; VI, col. 360, l. 24; col. 375, l. 5; col. 377, l. 2

person.name: Gilbertus d'Auvergnat
Gilbertus Alvergnat
Gilbertus Alverniaci
Gilbertus Auvergnaci
Gilbertus Auverniaci
person.note: From the diocese of Bourges (diocesis Bituricensis), bachelor in 1477, licensed in 1448 under the master Petrus Caroz. After some years of absence, he was elected procurator of the French nation from 1454 to 1456.

listBibl.bibl: Rouse & Rouse, Illiterati et uxorati, 34

person.name: Iacobus Louber
person.note: He studied in Basel in 1476–1477 and served as rector of Basel University. He subsequently entered the Carthusian order and became prior in 1480. Under his direction, the convent and the library were built.

listBibl.bibl: M. Burckhardt, “Aus dem Umkreis der ersten Basler Universitätsbibliothek”, Basler Zeitschrift für Geschichte und Altertumskunde 58/59 (1959), 155-191, at 176-179

person.name: Iacobus Pol
person.note: Iacobus Pol studied at the universities of Paris and Cologne, as attested by manuscripts Saint-Omer, Bibliothèque d'Agglomération du Pays de Saint-Omer, Ms 586 (copied in Paris), Ms 162 and Boulogne-sur-Mer, Bibliothèque Municipale, Ms. 28 (both of them copied in Cologne). The first manuscript, which contains Versoris's commentary on the natural philosophical corpus, bears the following possession mark: Hunc librum acquisivit frater Jacobus Pol, tempore quo fuit scolaris Parisiensis. The second manuscript, containing Iohannes Tinctoris's commentary on the first and third parts of Thomas Aquinas's Summa theologiae, includes two relevant notes. The first reads: pro fratre Iacobo Pol, monacho sancti Bertini in sancto Audomaro. The second, partially damaged by water, appears as follows: Incipit quedam lectura super primam et secundammy conjecture; the text is unreadable due to water damage partem beati Thome de Aquino, ad pennam pronunciata ab egregio viro, magistro Iohanne Tinctoris, artium magistro ac sacre theologie doctore famosissimo eiusdemque divine cultore precipuo to which another hand (the same as in the first ownership mark) adds: quam fecit scribi frater Iacobus, religiosus sancti Bertini, tempore quo mansit Colonie. The third manuscript, containing Iohannes de Mechelinis's Commentary on De divinis nominibus, contains the following ex-libris: Hunc librum fecit scribi fr. Jacobus Pol Colonie, pro monasterio Sancti Bertini, et fuit compositus per magistrum Iohannem de Mechelinia, professorem in theologia, tunc temporis in ipsa facultate regentem atque legente. Iacobus Pol entered the Benedictine monastery of Saint-Bertin before 1447. He served as prior twice: first between 1450 and 1473, and again from 1474 to 1481. He died in 1500.

listBibl.bibl: Grabmann, "Der belgische Thomist", 432-433
Livesey, Science in the monastery, 189-192

person.name: Iacobus Ungelink de Stendal
Iacobus Unghelinghe de Stendal
Iacobus Ungelink de Stendel
person.note: From the Diocese of Halberstadt, he studied at the Faculty of Arts in Paris as a member of the Anglo-German nation, obtaining the bachelor’s degree in 1465 and the master’s degree in 1467. He subsequently moved to Magdeburg, where he is attested at the Dominican convent between 1472 and 1486. In 1472 he lectured on natural philosophy based on the commentaries of Petrus de Rivo, as attested in the manuscript Berlin, Staatsbibliothek Preußischer Kulturbesitz, Magdeburg 220, f. 503va: Finitur lectura subtilis eximii sacre theologie professoris, magistri Petri de Rivo, Universitatis Lovaniensis ducatus Brabantini, super libros philosophie speculative Aristotelis, philosophi ingeniosissimi, quam ego, frater Dominicus de Zuuollis, scripsi et audivi in conventu nostro Magdeburgensi Ordinis Praedicatorum sub fratre Iacobo de Stendel, artium magistro preclaro Parisiensi, sub anno domini 1472. Eandem autem legi in conventu nostro alme Universitatis Rostochiensis sub anno domini 1476 [1486 add. alia manu].

listBibl.bibl: Auctarium II, col. 955, l. 36; VI, col. 397, l. 16; col. 429, l. 21; col. 440, l. 24

U. Winter, K. Heydeck, Die Manuscripta Magdeburgica der Staatsbibliothek zu Berlin Preußischer Kulturbesitz, Teil 3: Ms. Magdeb. 170–286, Wiesbaden 2007, 33–36, 189 (with indication of other manuscripts copied by him)

person.name: Iohannes Abbatis
Jean l'Abbé
person.note: From the diocese of Reims, he studied at the Faculty of Arts in Paris as a member of the French Nation. Between 1450 and 1452, he studied at the Collège de la Marche, as attested by manuscript Reims, Bibliothèque Carnegie (Bibliothèque municipale), 897 (I. 678). He was promoted baccalarius in 1452, and master in 1453. He later served as provost of the chapter of Reims Cathedral and as general vicar of the Archbishop of Reims. He owned other manuscripts now kept in Reims: 58, 562, 97, 705.

listBibl.bibl: Auctarium V, col. 478, l. 17; col. 526, l. 23; col. 529, l. 3

person.name: Iohannes Coromines
Iohannes Colomines
Iohannes Cormines
person.note: Originally from the Diocese of Barcelona (Dioecesis Barchinonensis), he was a member of the French Nation at the Faculty of Arts in Paris. He incepted in the Arts in 1444; studied theology under Robertus Ciboule and obtained his licentiate in 1458. He served as procurator of the French Nation from August 1447.
Student for whom Johannes Run copied the texts

person.note: Originally from the diocesis of Tréguier (Trecorensis) in Bretagne, he licensed and incepted at the Arts Faculty of the University of Paris in Mai 1444.

person.name: Michael de Turobin
Michał z Lublina i Turobina
person.note: Michael de Turobin studied at the University of Krakow, where he obtained the degree of Bachelor of Arts in 1477 and subsequently that of Doctor of Law. In 1527, he founded the Collegiate Church of Saint Anna in Krakow.

person.name: Michael Falkner de Wratislavia
Michał Falkener z Wrocławia
person.note: Matriculated at Cracow University in 1478 and obtained the degree of Master of Arts in 1488. He lectured at the Faculty of Arts until 1512 while studying theology; he became Doctor of Theology in 1517.

person.name: Nicolaus Unbehuen
Nicolaus Umbehauen
person.note: Active in Ulm, probably at the Dominican convent, in the third quarter of the fifteenth century.

listBibl.bibl: Leitschuh, I.1, 532-533.

person.name: Hilarius Litomericensis
Hilarius von Leitmeritz
Hilarius de Litomericz
Hilarius z Litoměřic
Hilarius Litoměřický
person.note: He studied philosophy at Prague University, where he obtained the bachelor's degree in 1447 and the master's degree in 1451. At that time, he supported the Hussite movement. His position changed after Jan Rokycana, the head of the Hussite clergy, sent him to study in Padua. Hilarius was promoted in canon law at the University of Bologna and converted to Catholicism. As a consequence, when he returned to Bohemia, he could not find a position at the Hussite-majority Prague University. From 1462 to his death, in 1468, he served as administrator of the Prague Chapter. He defended the authority of the pope against the Bohemian king Georg Podiebrad and, when tensions escalated, moved with the Chapter to Pilsen, where he coordinated the Catholic liga.
Author of a disputatio in ms. B 49; copyist of Versoris’s texts in ms. L 37

listBibl.bibl: Z. Kalista, "Die katholische Reform von Hilarius von Leitmeritz bis zum Weissen Berg", in F. Seibt (ed.), Bohemia Sacra. Das Christentum in Böhmen, 973–1973, Düsseldorf 1974, 110–144.

Heinrich Erlbach
person.note: After studying in Ingolstadt, he entered the Benedictine monastery of Saint Emmeram.

person.name: Petrus Świętopełk de Zambrzecz alias de Nieznanowice
Petrus Świętopełk de Rząbiec alias de Nieznanowice
person.note: He was enrolled at the University in 1446, became Master of Arts in 1460, was Provost of the Collegium Maius in 1479, Doctor of Theology in 1494, Canon of St. Florian; he died on 14 June 1497. He donated many books to the University.

person.name: Philippe Goupil
person.note: Originally from Rouen (Rothomagentis dyocesis), he studied at the Faculty of Arts in Paris under the Norman master Clément Parmentier in the years 1442–1444. He was appointed abbot of Saint Eve in Toul in 1480 and died in 1503.

listBibl.bibl: Monaci sancti Mauri ordinis sancti Benedicti, Gallia Christiana in provincias ecclesiasticas distributa, qua series et historia archiepiscoporum, episcoporum et abbatum regionum omnium quas vetus Gallia complecte et abbatum origine ecclesiarum ad nostra tempora deducitur et probatur ex authenticis instrumentis ad calcem appositis. Tomus decimus-tertius, ubi de provinciis Tolosana et Trevirensi agitur, Paris 1785, col. 1109
Livesey, Science in the Monastery, 189-192

person.name: Stanislaus de Velvary
Stanislaus de Welwara
Stanislav von Velvary
person.note: He obtained a Bachelor of Arts degree from Prague University in 1445. He later traveled to Paris, where he received minor orders from the Bishop of Paris and studied under Albertus Scriptoris at the House of the Poor German Students. Likely because his Prague degree was not recognized in Paris, he retook the bachelor examination and obtained a Bachelor of Arts degree from the University of Paris in 1450. The following year, he earned a Master of Arts degree. He subsequently returned to Prague, where he had a distinguished academic and ecclesiastical career: he was elected Dean of the Faculty of Arts in 1455 and served as Rector from 1456 to 1457. He was also appointed canon of Saint Apollinar and scholasticus of the Cathedral Chapter.

Mentioned in mss. Praha, KMK, M 40/2 and Praha, NK, X H 21 as the copyist who brought Versoris’s logical corpus from Paris to Prague; mentioned in ms. Wien, Dominikanerkonvent, Cod. 149/119 as the master under whom the copyist obtained his bachelor degree; using Versoris’s Ethics for teaching in ms. Praha, KMK, M 81

Gabriel, "The House of Poor German Students", 185–186

person.name: Stanislaus Petri de Byalkowicze
person.note: Matriculated at the University of Kraków in 1488; obtained the degree of bachelor in 1491. He served as magister regens between 1511 and 1524.

person.name: Stanisław z Czchowa, syn Macieja
person.note: matriculated at Cracow University in 1467.

person.name: Wenceslaus de Wrben
Václav z Vrbna
Wenzel von Vrbno
person.note: Originally from Bohemia, he traveled to Paris and studied at the College of the German Nation in 1445. Shortly thereafter, he went to Prague, where he became a Bachelor of Arts in November of the same year. He subsequently returned to Paris, this time accompanied by two colleagues, Clemens de Melnik and Stanislaus de Welwara, to complete the copy of the corpus attributed to Versoris. He returned to Prague in 1450 and was promoted to Master of Arts in 1451, under the mentorship of Jan Rokycana. That same year, he was elected Dean of the Faculty of Arts. He later served as Rector of the University in 1459–1460 and again in 1466. From 1462, he served as Dean of Saint Apollinar, and in the same year, he was sent on a diplomatic mission to Pope Pius II by King George of Poděbrady.

Copyist in ms. Praha, NK, IV E 25; mentioned in mss. Praha, KMK, L 37 and Praha, NK, I E 38 as the copyist of the natural philosophical corpus; mentioned in ms. Wien, Dominikanerkonvent, Cod. 149/119 as the copyist of the logical corpus.

listBibl.bibl: Šmahel, "Paris und Prag", 443, 445–447, 451, fn. 34
Gabriel, "The House of Poor German Students", 184–185
